article:
'Intelligent design' ('ID') is a form of creationism promulgated by the
Discovery Institute, a politically conservative think tank based in the United
States. The Institute defines it as the proposition that
"certain features of the universe and of living things are best explained by an
intelligent cause, not an undirected process such as natural selection." {{vcite web |url=http://www.discovery.org/csc/topQuestions.php#qu-
estionsAboutIntelligentDesign |title=Top Questions-1.What is the theory of
intelligent design? |publisher=Discovery Institute |accessdate=2012-06-16 }}
{{vcite web |url=http://www.ideacenter.org/stuff/contentmgr/files/393410a2d36e9-
b96329c2faff7e2a4df/miscdocs/intelligentdesigntheoryinanutshell.pdf
|title=Primer: Intelligent Design Theory in a Nutshell |publisher-
link=http://www.ideacenter.org/ |publisher=Intelligent Design and Evolution
Awareness Center |year=2004 |format=PDF |accessdate=2012-06-16 }} *{{vcite web
|url=http://www.intelligentdesignnetwork.org/ |title=Intelligent Design
|publisher=Intelligent Design network |year=2007 |accessdate=2012-06-16 }}
 It is a contemporary adaptation of the traditional teleological argument
for the existence of God, presented by its advocates as "an evidence-based
scientific theory about life's origins" rather than "a religious-based
idea". Meyer, Stephen C. (2005-12-01). "Not by chance". National Post
(CanWest MediaWorks Publications Inc. as sold to Postmedia Network Inc.).
Retrieved 2012-03-24. http://www.discovery.org/a/3059 All the leading
proponents of intelligent design are associated with the Discovery Institute


"Q. Has the Discovery Institute been a leader in the intelligent design
movement? A. Yes, the Discovery Institute's [[Center for Science and
Culture]]. Q. And are almost all of the individuals who are involved with
the intelligent design movement associated with the Discovery Institute? A.
All of the leaders are, yes." Barbara Forrest, 2005, testifying in the
Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District trial. {{vcite web
|url=http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/dover/day6pm.html |title=Kitzmiller v.
Dover Area School District Trial transcript: Day 6 (October 5), PM Session,
Part 1. |publisher=TalkOrigins Archive |year=2005 |accessdate=2012-06-16 }}
*"The Discovery Institute is the ideological and strategic backbone behind
the eruption of skirmishes over science in school districts and state
capitals across the country". In: {{vcite news
|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/21/national/21evolve.html
|title=Politicized Scholars Put Evolution on the Defensive |author=Jody
Wilgoren |work=The New York Times |date=August 21, 2005 |accessdate=2012-06-
16 }} *{{vcite web |title=Who is behind the ID movement? |work=Frequently
Asked Questions About "Intelligent Design" |publisher=American Civil
Liberties Union |date=September 16, 2005
|url=http://www.aclu.org/religion/schools/16371res20050916.html |accessdate=2012-06-
16 }} *{{vcite news |url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/index.php?-
command=view&program=DI%20Main%20Page%20-%20News&id=2745 |title=The
Evolution of George Gilder. The Author And Tech-Sector Guru Has A New Cause
To Create Controversy With: Intelligent Design |author=Kahn, JP |work=The
Boston Globe |date=July 27, 2005 |accessdate=2012-06-16 }} *{{cite web
|title=Who's Who of Intelligent Design Proponents |work=Science & Theology
News |month=November |year=2005 |url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/filesDB-
download.php?command=download&id=602 |accessdate=2007-07-20 |format=PDF }}
*"The engine behind the ID movement is the Discovery Institute". {{cite
journal |last=Attie |first=Alan D. |coauthors=Elliot Sober, Ronald L.
Numbers, Richard M. Amasino, Beth Cox4, Terese Berceau, Thomas Powell and
Michael M. Cox |title=Defending science education against intelligent
design: a call to action |journal=Journal of Clinical Investigation
|doi=10.1172/JCI28449 |publisher=A publication of the American Society for
Clinical Investigation. |year=2006
|url=http://www.jci.org/articles/view/28449 |accessdate=2012-06-16
|volume=116 |issue=5 |pages=1134â8 |pmid=16670753 |pmc=1451210 }}
{{cite web |url=http://www.aaas.org/spp/dser/03_Areas/evolution/issues/peer-
review.shtml |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071118222050/http://w-
ww.aaas.org/spp/dser/03_Areas/evolution/issues/peerreview.shtml
|title=Science and Policy: Intelligent Design and Peer Review
|publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |year=2007
|accessdate=2012-06-16 |archivedate=2007-11-18 }}

 and believe the designer to be the Christian deity.

"the writings of leading ID proponents reveal that the designer
postulated by their argument is the God of Christianity". {{cite court
|litigants=Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District |vol=04 |reporter=cv
|opinion=2688 |date=December 20, 2005 }}, . A selection of writings and
quotations of intelligent design supporters demonstrating this
identification of the Christian god with the intelligent designer are
found in the pdf [http://www.physics.smu.edu/pseudo/ID/HorsesMouth-
BP007.pdf Horse's Mouth] by Brian Poindexter, dated 2003. William A.
Dembski, a senior fellow of the Discovery Institute's Center for Science
and Culture, when asked in an interview whether his research concluded
that God is the Intelligent Designer, stated "I believe God created the
world for a purpose. The Designer of intelligent design is, ultimately,
the Christian God". {{cite web |url=http://www.uncommondescent.com/education/dembski-interviewed-over-
design-of-life/ |title=CitizenLink: Friday Five: William A. Dembski |accessdate=2012-06-
15 |author=Devon Williams |date=December 14, 2007 |publisher=Focus on
the Family }}



Scientific acceptance of Intelligent Design would require redefining science to
allow supernatural explanations of observed phenomena, an approach its
proponents describe as theistic realism or theistic science. It puts forth a
number of arguments in support of the existence of a designer, the most
prominent of which are irreducible complexity and specified complexity.

{{cite web |author=Stephen C. Meyer and Paul A. Nelson |date=May 1, 1996
|url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/index.php?command=view&id=1685
|title=CSC â Getting Rid of the Unfair Rules], A book review, Origins & Design
|accessdate=2007-05-20 }} *{{cite web |author=Phillip E. Johnson |date=August
31, 1996 |url=http://www.arn.org/docs/johnson/ratzsch.htm |title=Starting a
Conversation about Evolution |publisher=Access Research Network |work=Phillip
Johnson Files |accessdate=2012-06-16 }} *{{cite web |author=Stephen C. Meyer
|date=December 1, 2002 |publisher=Ignatius Press
|url=http://www.discovery.org/scripts/viewDB/index.php?command=view&id=1780
|title=The Scientific Status of Intelligent Design: The Methodological
Equivalence of Naturalistic and Non-Naturalistic Origins Theories }} *{{Cite
court |litigants=Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District |vol=04 |reporter=cv
|opinion=2688 |date=December 20, 2005 }}, *{{Cite court |litigants=Kitzmiller v.
Dover Area School District |vol=04 |reporter=cv |opinion=2688 |date=December 20,
2005 }}, . *See also
categories: Arguments for the existence of God
